item.title: The oldest European Soccer Player in the late 2000s
item.description: While doing some quality-checks in Kaggle Dataset ‚ÄúEuropean Soccer Database‚Äù, I found that in the late 2000s the oldest player active in top clubs was Tugay Kerimoƒülu, from Turkey. Born in 1970, he played the English Premier League until‚Ä¶ when, exactly?

item.title: The oldest European Soccer Player in the late 2000s
item.description: Still playing with a Soccer Database from Kaggle.com As an exercise, I wanted to find the oldest player participating in any match. My analysis also revealed a lot about the data quality of this Kaggle dataset. As mentioned in a previous blogpost, I‚Äôve downloaded a zipfile (36 MB) with Football data from data science community Kaggle.com. The archive contained an SQLite Database. library(DBI) con <- dbConnect(odbc::odbc(), "well-sqlite-footballdb") For the sake of brevity, to see the R packages I‚Äôve included to process the data, see the previous blogpost.

item.title: European Soccer Players and their BMI
item.description: Players in European soccer leagues have a Body Mass Index (BMI) that is normally distributed with a mean of 23 and an sd of 1.3. This is independent of body size.

item.title: European Soccer Players and their BMI
item.description: Playing with a Soccer Database from Kaggle.com Recently I‚Äôve downloaded as a zipfile (36 MB) from data science community Kaggle.com. This zipfile contains a single file, a 313 MB sqlite Database. Let‚Äôs take a peek what‚Äôs inside: Create connection to football DB library(DBI) con <- dbConnect(odbc::odbc(), "well-sqlite-footballdb") Read in R packages necessary to load the data: # tidyverse packages library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) # library(purrr) # functional programming library(stringr) library(lubridate) # strings to datetime library(ggplot2) theme_set(theme_bw()) The database consists of 7 tables.
